anyone tried using webp?
what do you mean try using
it works fine
unless of course its on web in which case the browser support is sad despite all of its clear benefits
want to know how much it influences speed, since supposed size difference is pretty huge
speed of what
loading from web, since we’re fetching a bunch of movie posters I’m thinking we could move to webp with it
but would it be worth it
on phone yes
There's pretty detailed compression study - <https://developers.google.com/speed/webp/docs/webp_study>
are these png or jpg images
if its PNG definitely worth it
yeah, PNGs
JPG you might need to test and validate some of images randomly
you can use something like this <https://github.com/seanooi/iOS-WebP>

text: should you need cross platform
gonna need that, tnx :simple_smile:
that example image they have there is a great example of how massive your savings can be assuming you are using something like a CDN to deliver the images
nearly 5x reduced, damn
well make sure you test some random images and validate that, I haven’t done that yet and that image has a ton of the same color in it
will have to first, esp since we’re going to have to do png->webp conversion on our backend
other articles I saw show mostly 3x reduction
yeah, grand scheme of things you should make your money back on the cpu cost almost immediately

"The use of WebP for transmitting Facebook images resulted in data savings of 25 to 35 percent compared with JPG, and 80 percent compared with PNG. This all happened without perceived impact on quality.” for facebook, that’s millions saved
let me know how it works out, would be interested in hearing a success story
will do
oh really?
see I just dont understand why browsers didnt all uniformly jump on it
like whats the down side im not hearing about
i can only assume its because its a google project and its trendy for browsers to say no thanks to anything google
that’s supposedly why mozzila didn’t want it at first
yeah but it has all those now doesn’t it?
yep, and they’re supposedly changing their mind
so in like 5 years MS will implement it into Edge
even with those complaints they still don’t make sense even if they are still valid
in a lot of cases those are acceptable trade offs
like yours
massive savings on something that just needs better compression
so going back to my assertion ‘its just trendy to reject google created software'
that probably has influence too
hm, operas seem to support it
damn it people have a google grudge

opera and google develop that together

oh the support

Can i disable LRU cache ? <@U04TK850N> <@U055GGAHS>
what?
whats the scope of this question
in a library or something?
Does the os keep objects in LRU Cache
like activities fragments bitmaps etc.
huh
Do you want to disable the activity history?
There is a dev setting for that
no
then I don’t know what you mean
But inferring from what you say I assume not without being rooted
oh
activities and fragments no
bitmaps use their own memory space but they are also not LRU cached
LRU caching is always left up to the developer since its something that every app will have a different  configuration need

generally a lot of apps use 1/8th or 1/4th available memory for LRU bitmap cache, cache for other types of objects are generally limited to a much smaller memory size but cases do exist where you have a lot more
my carving application allocates half the available app memory to byte[] allocations
just as an example
oh okay ...
in my particular case its not an LRU cache but an object pool
but close enough

Okay my next question is , when i start my app , memory  is around 140mb when i click on some item and go to next activity .. memory reaches to 178mb and when i come back .. it remains to 170 mb and never goes back .. What could be the reason ? There is no memory leak detected by leakcanary.
woahhh your app uses 140mb at start?
how? do you have largeHeap set to true in the manifest
Basically depends on the phone
o.O
well yes but it shouldn’t really be more than 20MB unless you have a really good reason
on high end phone it takes 140mb.. Samsung galaxy s6
but on low end phones it is around 60mb
where is that memory being allocated to
yeah that’s way too much
use the allocation tracker
you should be in the 15 - 20 MB range
where are you seeing these allocations
rather how do you know its 140 or 160 etc
even if largeHeap is set to true, it won't allocate so much at the start

Oh
Are you loading images into those byte arrays?
so that’s 123MB of byte arrays you have allocated
Pretty sure your listview adapter has an issue with your images
well hold on lets not jump to conclusions
if you click on the byte[] entry
you can get more information in the right hand panel
yes .. there are 426 instances
as for your question, <https://www.yourkit.com/docs/java/help/sizes.jsp>

its not easy to explain all of the columns nor is it truly necessary to understand them in most cases other than simply it is ideal to keep the number of objects in your application as low as possible and also keep the total memory allocated as low as possible
certain situations require you to go against those rules and thats ok, I dont think this is one of them though =P
I will read and try to understand :simple_smile:  . Sending the screenshot of right side

<@U053Q5XP2>: <@U0548MM6B> what does that letter say other than "Please don't do anything to Google, fragmentation is bad."?

<@U055GGAHS>: How would i find that large chunk of memory is allocated to which part?
if you have a suggestion for improvment, leave a comment
Someone who doesn't know what this might be harming
We can have new channel for such discussions.
<@U053Q5XP2>: I'd rather not have my name attached to something like that
allocation tracker would be best but hard to find it when it happens instantly at launch because you can’t start it fast enough
you need to look at once piece of code at a time and evaluate if that code is potentially holding on to the memory
the better way to do this is to use the eclipse MAT tool
it can tell you exactly what is holding the memory but that requires some knowledge to use
You should be able to break in Application.onCreate to start the allocation tracker
^ that’s a good idea
